style.name: wxDEFAULT_DIALOG_STYLE
style.description: Equivalent to a combination of wxCAPTION, wxCLOSE_BOX and wxSYSTEM_MENU (the last one is not used under Unix).

style.name: wxCAPTION
style.description: Puts a caption on the dialog box.

style.name: wxMINIMIZE_BOX
style.description: Displays a minimize box on the dialog.

style.name: wxMAXIMIZE_BOX
style.description: Displays a maximize box on the dialog.

style.name: wxCLOSE_BOX
style.description: Displays a close box on the dialog.

style.name: wxSTAY_ON_TOP
style.description: The dialog stays on top of all other windows.

style.name: wxRESIZE_BORDER
style.description: Display a resizable frame around the window.

style.name: wxNO_3D
style.description: Under Windows, specifies that the child controls should not have 3D borders unless specified in the control.

style.name: wxDIALOG_NO_PARENT
style.description: By default, a dialog created with a NULL parent window will be given the application's top level window as parent. Use this style to prevent this from happening and create an orphan dialog. This is not recommended for modal dialogs.

style.name: wxDIALOG_EX_CONTEXTHELP
style.description: Under Windows, puts a query button on the caption. When pressed, Windows will go into a context-sensitive help mode and wxWidgets will send a wxEVT_HELP event if the user clicked on an application window. Note that this is an extended style and must be set by calling SetExtraStyle() before Create is called (two-step construction).

style.name: wxDIALOG_EX_METAL
style.description: On Mac OS X, frames with this style will be shown with a metallic look. This is an extra style.

event.name: EVT_CLOSE
event.description: The dialog is being closed by the user or programmatically (see wxWindow::Close). The user may generate this event clicking the close button (typically the 'X' on the top-right of the title bar) if it's present (see the wxCLOSE_BOX style) or by clicking a button with the wxID_CANCEL or wxID_OK ids.
